Breast implant evaluation.clinical_scenario: Evaluation of saline breast implants. Any age. Initial imaging.
Breast implant evaluation.comment: US cannot detect saline leakage. Intervention is purely on clinical grounds

Breast implant evaluation.clinical_scenario: Evaluation of cosmetic silicone breast implants Suspected implant rupture/complication.
Breast implant evaluation.comment: Refer for privately funded imaging/surgical review -DHB specialist review/imaging not routinely accepted

Breast implant evaluation.clinical_scenario: Evaluation of non-cosmetic, silicone breast implants. Suspected implant rupture/complication. Any age. Initial imaging prior to Surgical review.
Breast implant evaluation.comment: GP-referred US then refer for review by initial operating surgeon if abnormal/equivocal

Breast implant evaluation.clinical_scenario: Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
Breast implant evaluation.modality: US +/- MR C- / US guided aspiration

Breast pain.clinical_scenario: Female with breast pain but no other suspicious clinical features or risk factors in history. Any age.
Female with clinically significant breast pain (focal and noncyclical) and lumpiness or other suspicious feature on exam and/or positive family history or other risk factor. Initial imaging.

Evaluation of the symptomatic male breas.clinical_scenario: Male patient any age with symptoms of gynecomastia and physical examination consistent with gynecomastia or pseudo-gynecomastia. No focal abnormality on exam
Evaluation of the symptomatic male breas.comment: Follow gynaecomastia pathway and plastics- referral criteria

Evaluation of the symptomatic male breas.clinical_scenario: Male any age with focal unilateral abnormality /indeterminate palpable breast mass. Initial imaging following breast specialist review

Male of any age with indeterminate palpable breast mass/ focal unilateral abnormality cancer (suspicious palpable breast mass, axillary adenopathy, nipple discharge, or nipple retraction). Initial imaging.

Imaging after mastectomy and breast reco.clinical_scenario: Clinically significant pain on the side of the mastectomy with or without reconstruction (autologous or non-autologous). Initial imaging.
Imaging after mastectomy and breast reco.comment: Any imaging done should be based on breast specialist review

Imaging after mastectomy and breast reco.clinical_scenario: Palpable lump on the side of the mastectomy with or without reconstruction (autologous or non-autologous). Initial imaging.

Palpable breast masses.clinical_scenario: Palpable breast mass. Female, <40 years of age, initial evaluation.
Palpable breast masses.comment: P3 unless >1mth duration or associated with another clinical/risk feature (e.g. If fixed, hard, FHx or palpable LNs) and then P2. (as per FCT criteria)

Palpable breast masses.clinical_scenario: Palpable breast mass. Female, 40 years of age or older, initial evaluation.
Palpable breast mass. Female, younger than 30 years of age, initial evaluation.
Palpable breast masses.comment: Upgrade to P2 if clinically suspicious

Evaluation of nipple discharge.clinical_scenario: Physiologic nipple discharge. Female of any age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Female younger than 30 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge. Male younger than 30 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Male or female 30 to 39 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Male or female 40 years of age or older. Initial imaging examination.

Monitoring response to neoadjuvant syste.clinical_scenario: Known breast cancer. Axillary evaluation prior to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Initial imaging examination.
Known breast cancer with clinical suspicion of metastatic disease. Staging or assessment of response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Initial imaging examination.

Staging known breast cancer.modality: CT CAP + bone scan or CT PET

Surveillance, history of breast cancer.clinical_scenario: Surveillance. Personal history of breast cancer. Asymptomatic. Rule out local recurrence.

Clinical suspicion of inflammatory breas.clinical_scenario: Clinical suspicion of inflammatory breast cancer

Follow up of findings on other imaging m.clinical_scenario: 2nd look imaging for findings on MRI or CT

Work up recommended by an MDM.clinical_scenario: Further work up, biopsy or imaging recommended by the Breast Multidisciplinary meeting

Post op seroma.clinical_scenario: Post operative seroma unable to be drained without imaging guidance

Follow up.clinical_scenario: Follow up imaging recommended on previous breast imaging

Recommended biopsy.clinical_scenario: Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably malignant or indeterminate lesion (including papilloma)
Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably benign lesion (suspected fibrocystic changes or fibroadenoma)

New diagnosis breast cancer.clinical_scenario: New diagnosis breast cancer with high background risk of undetected disease (e.g. BRCA-1; dense breasts) AND as recommended by MDM
Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS clear on mammogram and/or US
Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS NOT clear on mammogram or US and MR recommended by MDM
Non-calcified (typically high grade) DCIS to define extent for surgical planning and where recommended by MDM e.g. particularly with dense breasts
Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) where breast conserving surgery is being considered
Pre-and post- neoadjuvant chemotherapy, with a view to downstaging the lesion and allowing breast conserving surgery
Lumpectomy with a positive margin. If multiple positive margins, to move straight to mastectomy and nil MR
Fixed tumour, ?Invasion to deep fascia and neoadjuvant chemo or radiotherapy to establish a clear margin prior to surgery is being considered. Recommended by MDM

Breast symptoms evaluation.clinical_scenario: Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). No cause identified on DBI and ongoing concerns

Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
Breast symptoms evaluation.modality: US +/- MR C- / US guided aspiration

Presentation post treatment.clinical_scenario: Silicone implant (non-cosmetic) complications where the US is equivocal
Presentation post treatment.comment: Radiologist or clinician may indicate P3- non-deferrable

Surveillance, screening.clinical_scenario: Follow-up MRI surveillance of women could be considered, where initial presentation with palpable mass (biopsy positive) was occult on mammogram and ultrasound, but visible on MRI.

Acute chest pain.clinical_scenario: Chest pain syndrome - not clear ACS/intermediate probability of CAD

Suspected/new diagnosis of congenital he.clinical_scenario: Suspected/new diagnosis of congenital heart disease
Suspected/new diagnosis of congenital he.modality: XR ECHO MRI CTA IF CORO

Follow up congenital heart disease in th.clinical_scenario: Follow up congenital heart disease in the adult

Hypertension.clinical_scenario: Moderate or severe hypertension: diastolic pressure
High index of suspicion of renovascular hypertension and normal renal function
High index of suspicion of renovascular hypertension and diminished renal function

Pre-Operative.clinical_scenario: Cardiac valve surgery, non-urgent non-cardiac surgery
Urgent non-cardiac surgery e.g. cancer. Possible IHD

Operative.clinical_scenario: Dilated aorta, prior dissection, prior aortic surgery or stent

Left lower quadrant pain.comment: CT first unless pain suggests pelvic origin more likely

Palpable abdominal mass.clinical_scenario: Palpable mass, high or moderate suspicion of cancer clinically
Palpable mass, low clinical suspicion for cancer or pulsatile and painless

Colorectal screening.clinical_scenario: Average-risk individual after positive faecal occult blood test (FOBT), indicating a relative elevation in risk
Average-risk, moderate-risk or high-risk individual after incomplete colonoscopy
Moderate-risk individual: personal history or adenoma or carcinoma or first-degree family history of cancer or adenoma
High-risk individual: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Pre-treatment staging of colorectal canc.comment: Deferrable only while having pre-op chemo
Deferrable only while having pre-op chemo

Miscellaneous.prioritisation_category: P4 or P2 if red flags

Neuroendocrine.comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal
P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal
P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

Neuroendocrine.clinical_scenario: Growth hormone deficiency, growth deceleration, panhypopituitarism
Neuroendocrine.comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

Thyroid.clinical_scenario: Palpable thyroid nodule, suspicious features (e.g. painless rapid growth over 2-3 months, history of voice change +/or stridor, youth/child, family history of MEN, neck nodes), euthyroid, initial imaging
Palpable thyroid nodule, no suspicious features for thyroid cancer, euthyroid, initial imaging
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH normal or elevated and >1.5cm if >35y and >1.0cm if <35y
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH reduced.
Incidental FDG-avid nodule on PET CT
Suspected goitre. Initial imaging. Obstructive symptoms
Thyroid cancer, surgery considered, anaplastic ca or metastatic disease suspected

Adrenal lesion.clinical_scenario: No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter. Initial evaluation.
Adrenal lesion.modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

Adrenal lesion.clinical_scenario: No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter. Follow-up evaluation in 12 months.
Adrenal lesion.modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

Adrenal lesion.clinical_scenario: No history of malignancy; mass >4 cm in diameter. (If not typical for adenoma, myelolipoma, haemorrhage or simple cyst, consider resection). Clinical review pre-biopsy.
Adrenal lesion.modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

Adrenal lesion.clinical_scenario: History of malignancy; mass > 4 cm in diameter. Clinical review pre-biopsy.

Acute shoulder pain.clinical_scenario: Any aetiology; best initial study, (septic arthritis not-suspected clinically)
X-ray non-contributory. Persistent significant pain. Physical examination and history nonspecific. Next study.
X-ray non-contributory. Age less than 35 years, suspect labral tear with or without instability on physical examination.
X-ray non-contributory. Questionable bursitis or long head of biceps tenosynovitis based on clinical findings including physical examination.
Normal x-ray or x-ray demonstrates coracoacromial arch osteophytes/syndesmophytes. Suspect rotator cuff tear/ impingement, over 35 years.
Acute shoulder pain.comment: US first investigation. If concern of complete tendon tear especially subscapularis and especially in younger patients, then P3 or less is better

Acute shoulder pain.clinical_scenario: X-ray non-contributory. Previous total shoulder arthroplasty. Suspect rotator cuff tear.
X-ray non-contributory. Status post prior rotator cuff repair. Suspect re-tear.
Acute shoulder pain.comment: P3. Earlier timeframe better for potential surgical repair. US first

Chronic shoulder pain.modality: XR, then US if normal XR and cuff tear suspected

Acute elbow pain.clinical_scenario: Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; ossicles on x-ray
Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; X-rays NAD
Suspect occult injury e.g. osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect unstable osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect collateral ligament tear; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Acute elbow pain.comment: In rare situation of grossly unstable elbow and considering acute ligament repair/reconstructive surgery then MRI within 2 days appropriate. Otherwise all ligament investigations by specialist only and category P 4 and deferrable

Acute elbow pain.clinical_scenario: Suspect biceps tendon tear and/or bursitis; radiographs non-diagnostic.
Acute elbow pain.comment: if distal biceps tear should be P2. U/S first if suspect complete tear. MRI for query partial tear or if diagnosis uncertain

Chronic elbow pain.comment: XR first- further imaging e.g. US, based on clinician review

Acute hand and wrist trauma.clinical_scenario: Suspect acute distal radius fracture. Radiographs normal. Next procedure.
Comminuted, intra-articular distal radius fracture on radiographs. Surgical planning.
Suspect acute scaphoid fracture. X-rays normal. Next procedure.
Suspected occult scaphoid fracture. Initial and repeat x-rays after 10-14 days of casting normal. Continued clinical suspicion of scaphoid fracture. Next procedure.
Acute hand and wrist trauma.comment: P2 i.e. patient already in cast

Acute hand and wrist trauma.clinical_scenario: Suspect hook of the hamate fracture. Initial radiographs normal or equivocal.
Acute hand and wrist trauma.comment: CT first and then MRI if occult fracture still suspected

Acute hand and wrist trauma.clinical_scenario: Suspect gamekeeper injury (thumb MCP ulnar collateral ligament injury).
Acute hand and wrist trauma.modality: XR then US if normal XR
Acute hand and wrist trauma.comment: XR P1 if NAD, then US P2>P3

Chronic wrist pain.clinical_scenario: With or without prior injury. Best initial study.
Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Persistent symptoms. Next study.
Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Suspect arthritis ( other than septic). Next study.
Nonspecific arthritis on x-ray. Exclude infection. Next study.
Pain on ulnar side, suspect triangular fibrocartilage or lunotriquetral ligament tear. Radiographs normal. Next study.
X-rays show positive ulnar variance and irregularity in proximal lunate articular surfaces. Next study.
X-rays normal or equivocal. Suspect Kienbock's disease. Next study.
Kienbock's disease on x-rays. Next study.
Pain for more than 3 weeks. Suspect occult fracture. Radiographs nondiagnostic. Next study.

Chronic wrist pain.modality: Usually none/ XR only if concern of contributory arthritis

Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of th.comment: MRI if XR normal or inconclusive

Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of th.clinical_scenario: Avascular necrosis with femoral head collapse on x-ray of the painful hip
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of th.comment: MRI only if requested by subspecialty hip surgeon. Deferrable if no surgery contemplated.

Chronic hip pain.clinical_scenario: Initial evaluation for chronic hip pain. First test.
Rapidly increasing hip pain, not typical for usual OA progression
Chronic hip pain.comment: e.g. active inflammatory arthritis and rapid destruction and collapse of the femoral head

Chronic hip pain.clinical_scenario: X-rays negative, suspect osseous or surrounding soft-tissue abnormality, excluding osteoid osteoma.
X-rays negative, suspect osteonecrosis. Includes circumstances in which hip is asymptomatic but osteonecrosis is suspected due to known predisposing factors.

Chronic hip pain.comment: MRI first and if negative consider CT and bone scan

Chronic hip pain.clinical_scenario: X-rays negative, suspect labral tear with or without clinical findings consistent with or suggestive or femoro-acetabular impingement.
X-rays negative or mild osteoarthritis. Suspect referred pain but wish to exclude hip.
X-rays positive, arthritis uncertain type. Infection not a consideration.
Radiographs positive, suggestive of pigmented villo-nodular synovitis or osteochondromatosis.

Non traumatic knee pain.clinical_scenario: Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate degenerative joint disease and/or chondrocalcinosis.

Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate inflammatory, crystalline, or degenerative joint disease (uni- to tri-compartmental sclerosis, hypertrophic spurs, joint space narrowing, and/or subchondral cysts).
Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate avascular necrosis.
Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee radiographs x-rays evidence of internal derangement (e.g. Segond fracture, deep lateral femoral notch sign).

Imaging after Total Knee arthroplasty.clinical_scenario: Pain after TKA: positive aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA: positive x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA: negative x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Routine follow-up of asymptomatic patients with TKA.

Chronic ankle pain.clinical_scenario: Chronic ankle pain of any origin - best initial study.
Multiple sites of degenerative joint disease by ankle x-rays. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected osteochondral injury. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected tendon abnormality. Next study.

Acute ? bone tumour.clinical_scenario: Definitively benign on x-rays (excluding osteoid osteoma).
Acute ? bone tumour.comment: (unless risk of # and aggressive benign appearance and then P2)

Acute ? bone tumour.clinical_scenario: Suspicious for malignant characteristics on x-ray

Acute ? soft tissue tumour.clinical_scenario: Soft-tissue mass: abdominal or chest wall.
Acute ? soft tissue tumour.comment: Often CT first to confirm lesion, then MRI for further characterisation

Acute ? soft tissue tumour.clinical_scenario: Calcified soft-tissue mass not definitely benign seen on x-rays.
Negative or nonspecific findings on x-rays in area of palpated mass.
Follow-up of spontaneous soft-tissue haemorrhage in older adults.

Follow up of malignant or aggressive MSK.clinical_scenario: Lower-risk patient (low grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Higher-risk patient (high grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Evaluation for osseous metastatic disease from musculoskeletal primary.

Ataxia.clinical_scenario: Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child).

Cerebrovascular disease.clinical_scenario: Asymptomatic. Structural lesion on physical examination (cervical bruit) and/or risk factors.
Cerebrovascular disease.comment: Asymptomatic carotid bruit not routinely imaged

Epilepsy.clinical_scenario: Chronic epilepsy, poor therapeutic response. Surgery candidate.
New onset seizure. ETOH, and/or drug related.
New onset seizure. Older than age 40.

Focal neurological deficit.clinical_scenario: Single or multiple focal neurologic deficits.

Headache.clinical_scenario: New headache in patients older than age 60. Sedimentation rate higher than 55, temporal tenderness. Suspected temporal arteritis.
Headache.comment: May be nil imaging if clinically confident of the diagnosis

Neurodegenerative Disorders.clinical_scenario: Suspected vascular dementia or rapidly progressive dementia or mixed vascular dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
Suspected prion disease (Creutzfeldt-Jakob, iatrogenic CJ, or variant CJ)

Neurodegenerative Disorders.comment: Depends on clinical setting. In the subacute setting, CT may be helpful for immediate management, with MRI only if needed.

Neurodegenerative Disorders.clinical_scenario: Clinical features suggestive of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA).
Parkinson's disease: typical clinical features and responds to levodopa.
Parkinsonian syndrome: atypical clinical features not responsive to levodopa.

Neurodegenerative Disorders.comment: P3, not deferrable (can be useful occasionally), given the nature of this condition should be done <6 weeks. Spine may be required also.

Demyelination/MS.clinical_scenario: Routine 12-month follow up, on medication for MS
Follow up of MS with ?new relapse

Cerebrovascular.clinical_scenario: Risk for unruptured aneurysm. Positive family history.
Cerebrovascular.comment: MRA>CTA due to radiation and better to have same baselines for follow up
Case by case, some should have repeat DSA in a week, others just MRA or longer interval

Space occupying lesion.clinical_scenario: Follow up of glioma/GBM and considering treatment (e.g. is nodular enhancement enlarging)
Follow up of glioma/GBM with new/worsening symptoms

Abnormal vaginal bleeding.comment: Follow up scan would be at referring clinician’s discretion and time accordingly however would be non-deferable from the specified time.
This is a large cohort of pts and individual consideration to cases is needed to determine time frame. If any high-risk clinical factors may need to be triaged P2.
Follow up scan post endometrial sampling or other management may not always be mandatory e.g. after removal of endo polyp. If high clinical risk, then triage 3 or even P2 if symptomatic anaemia.

Abnormal vaginal bleeding.clinical_scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up of multi-fibroid uterus as per clinician/ radiologist recommendation
Abnormal vaginal bleeding.comment: Relatively low risk , e.g. on clinical discretion a follow up of multi-fibroid uterus is required S4.

Palpable adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.

Clinically suspected adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.
Clinically suspected adnexal mass.comment: If a suspected mass with pain or bleeding then P2, otherwise P3.

Clinically suspected adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography; NOT clearly malignant. Follow-up recommendations.
Clinically suspected adnexal mass.comment: Can be planned triage as either 6 weeks or 3 months follow up ultrasound depending on clinician recommendation or MDM review.

Clinically suspected adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography getting smaller at short-term follow-up. (If resolved, no further imaging necessary).
Clinically suspected adnexal mass.comment: Could defer to a 4 depending on symptoms, clinical risk and tumour markers. Clinician to indicate.

Clinically suspected adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass that is persistent or enlarging on pelvic sonography at short-term follow-up.
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial sonography demonstrates a large and apparently simple cyst >6 cm in diameter.
Clinically suspected adnexal mass.comment: Could defer to a P4 depending on symptoms. Clinician to indicate.

Clinically suspected adnexal mass.clinical_scenario: Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea). Initial evaluation.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst >5 cm in diameter by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst 3-5 cm in diameter seen by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a complex or solid adnexal mass seen by pelvic sonography.

Staging of gynaecological cancers.clinical_scenario: Pre-treatment of ovarian cancer or rule out recurrence
Invasive cancer of the cervix, FIGO stage 1b1 or greater

Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.clinical_scenario: Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG positive
Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.comment: If ectopic pregnancy suspected - same day imaging

Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.clinical_scenario: Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG negative.
Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.comment: Triage depends on clinical indication: acute versus chronic pain, associated bleeding. For example, acute pain ovarian torsion, haemorrhagic cyst etc will need triage P1. However, other pain non-specified could be triage P2. Clinician to indicate urgency.

Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.clinical_scenario: Non Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG positive.
Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive ag.comment: Early pregnancy causes of pain not related to pregnancy i.e. UTI, appendicitis, ovarian, gallbladder.

Pain in pregnancy.comment: Scan to be tailored to location of pain i.e. Maternal adnexa, gallbladder, kidneys, appendix, placenta (abruption) etc. Assessment of foetal wellbeing is always required at a minimum as well unless pain is clearly renal or GB in origin.

Bleeding in pregnancy.comment: According to HealthPathways, urgency depends on clinical risk factors - if ectopic suspected or bleeding severe may need to be within 24 hours

Bleeding in pregnancy.clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms.
Bleeding in pregnancy.comment: Scan to determine cause of APH i.e. Placenta praevia, vasa praevia, placental abruption may need vaginal ultrasound. Growth assessment can be performed if due.

Bleeding in pregnancy.clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa diagnosed before 32 weeks.
Bleeding in pregnancy.comment: Any longer wait-time e.g. P2 should be at clinical discretion - including where already excluded vasa praevia on previous scan or already diagnosed placenta praevia or low-lying placenta at anatomy scan.

Bleeding in pregnancy.clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Uterine contractions, pain, > 20 weeks
2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Persistent low-lying placenta.
Bleeding in pregnancy.comment: Deferral to P2 at clinical discretion only

Bleeding in pregnancy.clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa, history of caesarean delivery.
Bleeding in pregnancy.comment: Need to exclude placenta accreta. May need transvaginal scan. If first scan triage P1. If placenta accreta already known from a previous scan, then can triage P2 or tailored/planned/32 weeks follow up based on clinician recommendation from previous MDM or other earlier discussions.

Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).comment: Risk of foetal demise if severe and poorly managed.

Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).clinical_scenario: Small foetus, low or low normal fluid, follow-up studies
Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).comment: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician..

Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).clinical_scenario: Very small foetus, normal fluid, follow-up studies
Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).comment: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferable.

Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).clinical_scenario: Normal sized foetus, low or absent fluid, follow-up studies
Growth disturbance (risk IUGR).comment: Follow up to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferrable.

Assessment of gravid cervix.clinical_scenario: Patient at risk for preterm delivery: 16-24 weeks gestation: cervical length ≥3cm on transvaginal ultrasound scan
Assessment of gravid cervix.comment: standard 2 week follow up screening scan for cervical length 16-24 weeks or as advised by PTB clinic

Assessment of gravid cervix.clinical_scenario: Patient at risk for preterm delivery (history of prior preterm birth or multiple gestations): 16-24 weeks gestation: cervix ≤3 cm long by transvaginal ultrasound scan
Assessment of gravid cervix.comment: May need a follow up scan sooner than standard 2-week interval at clinician discretion

Assessment of gravid cervix.clinical_scenario: 2nd or third trimester assessment of cervix after 24 weeks
Assessment of gravid cervix.comment: Assessment of cervical cerclage or monitoring of open cervix after 24 weeks gestation. Scan timing at clinician discretion depending on indication.

Neck mass/lymphadenopathy.clinical_scenario: Adult presenting with a non-pulsatile solitary neck mass (afebrile).
Adult presenting with multiple neck masses.
Adult with a history of treatment for cancer presenting with a neck mass.

Sino-nasal disease.clinical_scenario: Recurrent acute or chronic rhinosinusitis (possible surgical candidate).

Vertigo and hearing loss.clinical_scenario: Sensorineural hearing loss, acute and intermittent vertigo.
Conductive hearing loss, to rule out petrous bone abnormality.
Total deafness, cochlear implant candidate, surgical planning.
Fluctuating hearing loss, history of meningitis or to rule out congenital anomaly.
Vertigo, no hearing loss, normal neurological examination.

Cranial neuropathy.clinical_scenario: Anosmia and abnormalities of the sense of smell.
Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of mastication; sensory abnormalities of the head and neck.
Weakness or paralysis of facial expression.
Weakness or paralysis of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
Weakness or paralysis of the tongue.

Dysphagia.clinical_scenario: Oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause.

General neurology.clinical_scenario: Developmental delay, cerebral palsy, spinal dysraphism

Seizures.clinical_scenario: Seizures with regression or arrest in development
Generalised seizures, no neurology, even if intractable

Headache.clinical_scenario: Progressive headache without neurological signs or symptoms of raised ICP
Chronic headache with no neurological signs

Ataxia.clinical_scenario: Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child)

Focal neurological deficits.clinical_scenario: Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, stable, or incompletely resolving
Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, progressive
Single focal neurologic deficit, completely resolving

Neuroendocrine.comment: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal
P1 if abnormal visual fields or ↑prolactin otherwise P3

Neuroendocrine.clinical_scenario: Variant 7 - Growth hormone deficiency, growth deceleration, panhypopituitarism
Neuroendocrine.comment: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal

ENT.clinical_scenario: Child (up to age 14) presenting with a solitary neck mass or multiple neck masses (afebrile)

Children with persistent (acute sinusiti.clinical_scenario: Children with persistent (acute sinusitis that does not respond to treatment), recurrent, or chronic sinusitis

Children with sinusitis with orbital or.clinical_scenario: Children with sinusitis with orbital or intracranial complications

Musculoskeletal.clinical_scenario: DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, hip instability or dislocation detected or suspected on exam.
DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, breech presentation or positive family history, stable hips on exam
DDH - Patient 4 months of age or older, clinically suspicious for DDH (limited abduction or abnormal gait)
Limp - Focal clinical examination (not septic arthritis)

Respiratory.comment: Annual + prn CXR. US for portal hypertension age 5 then annual or prn. HRCT age 6.

Gastrointestinal.clinical_scenario: IBD extension of disease or symptomatic

Urology.clinical_scenario: Uncomplicated UTI, age <6 months, first episode
Recurrent infections (>/=2 episodes of culture positive UTI or high suspicion previous episode/s missed)
Gross, painless haematuria and no evident cause
Persistent, isolated microscopic haematuria on urine microscopy (>1 year) without proteinuria and increased urinary calcium or calcium creatinine ratio
Dipstick positive proteinuria and confirmed on PCR on early morning sample, when child is well

Acute respiratory illness.comment: P3 if CXR showed mass like pneumonia, looked like pneumonia but with no signs of infection, or looked like a pneumonia with pleural fluid. P4 if standard typical pneumonia (AV)

Chronic dyspnoea- suspected pulmonary or.clinical_scenario: Older than age 40, negative physical examination.
Younger than age 40, negative physical exam. Positive with other symptoms, severe dyspnoea, or other risk factors.
Younger than age 40, negative physical examination.
Any age, non-revealing or non-diagnostic clinical, standard radiography, and laboratory studies.
Chronic dyspnoea- suspected pulmonary or.comment: Duration and severity dependant. P3 if symptoms <2 months or >2months if progressive. P4 if >2 months

Haemoptysis.clinical_scenario: Persistent/recurrent haemoptysis >40 years old +/- smoking history
Haemoptysis.comment: P2 CXR first then P3 CT if CXR normal

?Rib fracture.comment: CXR only if surgical emphysema or asymmetrical signs

Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR.clinical_scenario: Nodule ≥ 1 cm and </= 3cms, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR.comment: P3 if no previous imaging P4 if stable

Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR.clinical_scenario: Nodule ≥ 1 cm and </= 3cms, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.
Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR.comment: Consider direct referral for CT PET if resectable on CXR

Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR.clinical_scenario: Nodule ≤ 1 cm, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
Nodule ≤ 1 cm, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.

Lung cancer staging.clinical_scenario: Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest curative
Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest non-curative

Routine admission and pre-operative ches.clinical_scenario: Acute cardiopulmonary findings by history or physical.
Chronic cardiopulmonary disease in the elderly (age >70), previous chest radiograph within 6 months available.
Chronic cardiopulmonary disease in the elderly (age >70), previous chest radiograph within 6 months not available.

Pleural disease.modality: CXR, +/-US and drainage, +/- CT (as per comment)
Pleural disease.comment: Large effusion- P2 CXR, and , US and drainage Small effusion or PHx of cancer -. P2 CXR + CT

Low back pain.clinical_scenario: Uncomplicated acute low back pain and/or radiculopathy, nonsurgical presentation. No red flags*
Low back pain.comment: (See Red flags below as per ACR update 2021 -systematic review based).

Low back pain.clinical_scenario: Low velocity trauma, osteoporosis, and /or age > 70 years, X-ray NAD or nil unexpected
Suspicion of cancer, infection, or immunosuppression, XR NAD/ non-contributory.
Low back pain and/or radiculopathy, surgery or intervention candidate, XR NAD or nil unexpected.
Prior lumbar surgery, XR NAD or nil unexpected.

Spinal infection.clinical_scenario: Follow up, routine, no new symptoms

Plexopathy.clinical_scenario: Brachial - acute onset or chronic plexopathy without trauma, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Brachial - entrapment syndromes, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Brachial - post-treatment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - acute onset or chronic plexopathy without trauma, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - entrapment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - post-treatment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings

Myelopathy (see neuro also).clinical_scenario: Slowly progressive, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings

Stress insufficiency fractures including.clinical_scenario: Suspect stress/insufficiency fracture. First imaging modality.
Suspect stress fracture in patient with need-to-know diagnosis, not hip or sacrum. X-rays normal.
Suspect stress fracture, not hip or sacrum. X-rays normal. Bone scan positive and nonspecific.
Suspect stress fracture in otherwise normal patient. X-rays and bone scan or MRI normal.
Clinical differential insufficiency fracture versus metastasis in sacrum. X-rays normal, bone scan hot but nonspecific.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in sacrum/pelvis; elderly patient. X-rays normal. Bone scan hot in a linear pattern typical for fracture.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in osteoporotic patient or patient on long-term corticosteroid therapy, not hip. X-rays normal.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in osteoporotic patient or patient on long-term corticosteroid therapy; not hip. X-rays and bone scan or MRI normal at 48 hours.
Suspect sub-acute insufficiency fracture of hip in osteoporotic patient or patient on corticosteroid therapy. X-rays normal.

Chronic neck pain.clinical_scenario: Patient of any age, without a history of previous trauma, first study.
Patient of any age, history of previous malignancy, first study.
Patient of any age, history of previous neck surgery, no red flags, first study.
Chronic neck pain.comment: If any red flags, then P2

Chronic neck pain.clinical_scenario: X-rays normal. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show spondylosis. No neurologic findings.
X-rays show spondylosis. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show old trauma. No neurologic findings.
X-rays show old trauma. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show bone or disc margin destruction.

Right upper quadrant pain.clinical_scenario: No fever, normal WBC, ultrasound shows only gallstones

Palpable abdominal mass.clinical_scenario: Palpable mass, high suspicion of cancer clinically
Palpable mass, low-mod clinical suspicion for cancer or pulsatile and painless

Jaundice.clinical_scenario: Painless, one or more of the following: weight loss, fatigue, anorexia, duration of symptoms greater than 3 months. Patient otherwise healthy.
Painless, one or more of the following: weight loss, fatigue, anorexia, duration of symptoms greater than 3 months. Patients who will not tolerate radical surgical procedure.
Clinical condition and laboratory examination make mechanical obstruction unlikely.
Confusing clinical picture, patient not described in previous scenarios.

Liver lesion characterisation.clinical_scenario: Typical benign on initial imaging, no history of malignancy
Typical benign on initial imaging, known history of extrahepatic malignancy
Typical malignant hepatic mass on initial imaging
Indeterminate on initial imaging, 1cm, no suspicion or evidence of extrahepatic malignancy or liver disease
Liver lesion characterisation.comment: MDM review and clinical risk assessment for target date and type of imaging tailored

Liver lesion characterisation.clinical_scenario: Indeterminate solitary mass on initial imaging, >1cm, known history of extrahepatic malignancy
Liver lesion characterisation.comment: but MDM review and clinical risk assessment for target date and type of imaging tailored

Liver lesion characterisation.clinical_scenario: Indeterminate mass on initial imaging, >1cm, known or suspected liver disease associated with a high risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, hemochromatosis, etc)
Liver lesion characterisation.comment: but MDM review and clinical risk assessment for target date and type of imaging tailored
MDM review and clinical risk assessment for target date and type of imaging tailored

Suspected liver metastases.clinical_scenario: Initial imaging test following detection of primary tumour
Surveillance following treatment of primary tumour
Abnormal surveillance US, CT or MRI, or PVP: high suspicion of malignancy

Crohn's disease.clinical_scenario: Adult with known Crohn's disease and fever, increasing pain, leucocytosis etc
Crohn's disease.comment: MR Enterography>CT depending on how unwell and may be <4 weeks

Crohn's disease.clinical_scenario: Adult with known Crohn's disease; stable, mild symptoms

Dysphagia.clinical_scenario: Oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause

Urinary tract calculi.comment: Dependent on symptoms and renal function and according to protocol

Male UTI.clinical_scenario: Adult male who has a recurrent or persistent infection, or a single episode of pyelonephritis

Female UTI.clinical_scenario: Adult females who are non-responders to prophylactic antibiotics AND get frequent reinfections (≥2 in 6 months OR ≥ 3 in 1 year)

Haematuria.clinical_scenario: Patients >40 years and <85 years with painless macroscopic haematuria and eGFR >45
Patients >40 years and <85 years with lab-confirmed microscopic haematuria on >2 occasions and in absence of proteinuria, pyuria and eGFR>45
Patients <40 years or >85 years with macroscopic haematuria or confirmed microscopic haematuria

Renal failure.clinical_scenario: Chronic renal failure and eGFR <30 or <45 with diabetes, or progressive drop in eGFR>5 over 12 months or with significant proteinuria (urine ACR>30) or associated haematuria.
Renal failure.comment: Not deferrable if acute on chronic

Renal lesions.clinical_scenario: Post-surgical RCC, asymptomatic patient; no known metastases
Renal lesions.comment: For annual surveillance, if < annual interval, rank 2

Bladder lesions.comment: Depends on cystoscopy P3 or P4 non deferrable may be OK

Bladder lesions.clinical_scenario: F/U Superficial TCC; no invasion or risk factors.
F/U Invasive TCC with or without cystectomy.
Bladder lesions.comment: For annual surveillance, if < annual interval, rank 2

Bladder lesions.clinical_scenario: F/U Superficial TCC; no invasion; with risk factors.

Miscellaneous.comment: Dependent on age, severity and renal function

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Sudden onset of cold, painful leg
Pulsatile abdominal mass, suspected asymptomatic AAA
Vascular.comment: US is a validated investigation especially for community referrals

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Claudication - suspected vascular aetiology, failed conservative management (exercise program)
Vascular.comment: US by vascular sonographer may be considered if not already performed

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Follow-up of lower limb arterial bypass surgery
Vascular.comment: NB Lengthy deferrals may put grafts at risk

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Recurrent symptoms following lower limb angioplasty - claudication
Recurrent symptoms following lower limb angioplasty - threatened limb

Vascular.comment: CTA as alternative if vascular US expertise not available.

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Aneurysm/graft surveillance - AAA, visceral, iliac or popliteal
US detected abnormality on stent surveillance
Vascular.comment: - highly variable depending on severity of stenosis

Vascular.clinical_scenario: Dialysis fistula - complication suspected including occlusion, steal, stenosis

Diabetic foot.clinical_scenario: Neuroarthropathy with ulceration but no infection
Deteriorating ulceration with evidence of arterial disease
